title: How to Make a Child's Birthday List a Little More Fun

steps.headline: Sit down with your child and ask him/her what they want for their birthday.
steps.description: If your child can write and spell properly, skip to step 2. As your child tells you what they want, write each item down on a separate post-it.

steps.headline: If your child can write and spell properly, ask them to write down each thing they want on a separate post-it.
Put all the post-its (folded in half) in the container.
(Optional) Let the child decorate the box with items such as colored paper, stickers, glitter, etc.
Pull a random post-it out of the container when relatives or friends call asking what to get your child for their birthday and tell them what was written on the post-it.
steps.description: If they say they will get it, do not put in the container, but keep it in a hidden spot, in case the person ends up not getting the item, you can simply just put the post-it back in the container.

steps.headline: Let the child check the box everyday as anticipation builds up inside of them as they see more and more post-its disappear.
steps.description: Just don't let him/her read the remaining post-its or they will know what they are getting.

text: Sit down with your child and ask him/her what they want for their birthday. If your child can write and spell properly, skip to step 2. As your child tells you what they want, write each item down on a separate post-it. If your child can write and spell properly, ask them to write down each thing they want on a separate post-it.  Put all the post-its (folded in half) in the container.  (Optional) Let the child decorate the box with items such as colored paper, stickers, glitter, etc.  Pull a random post-it out of the container when relatives or friends call asking what to get your child for their birthday and tell them what was written on the post-it. If they say they will get it, do not put in the container, but keep it in a hidden spot, in case the person ends up not getting the item, you can simply just put the post-it back in the container. Let the child check the box everyday as anticipation builds up inside of them as they see more and more post-its disappear. Just don't let him/her read the remaining post-its or they will know what they are getting.
